newsitem.title: UK: IPE Brent ends firm, near highs, in heat-led rally.
newsitem.headline: IPE Brent ends firm, near highs, in heat-led rally.

text.p: IPE Brent crude futures closed sharply higher on Thursday following a technical rally inspired first by local gas oil futures and then by NYMEX heating oil, brokers said.
Sept Brent closed 52 cents up at $20.73 a barrel, having touched, but failed to breach, key resistance at $20.80. The Sep/Oct backwardation widened six cents to 52 cents a barrel.
The market dipped in late afternoon trade amid confusion over the timing of Iraqi oil exports, but retraced gains when reports were clarified.
"The strength is basically on technicals," said one broker.
"We were strong this morning and NYMEX's performance just confirmed the move," another said.
IPE gas oil, buoyed by low inventories, led up the oil complex before the NYMEX open.
September gas oil closed up $3.00 at $191.00 a tonne, just off a session and contract high of $191.50. The Oct Brent/gas oil crack spread ended higher at $4.73 a barrel.
Trading volumes for Brent and gas oil were reported thin.
Brokers said that news of a fire at Tosco's Bayway, New Jersey refinery and the brief closure of the Sumed crude oil pipeline lent only fleeting support to the market.
Brent futures stumbled in late afternoon trade, sliding close to opening lows, on the perception that Iraqi oil exports could resume shortly.

A U.N. official said in New York that technical arrangements to implement the oil-for-food deal, which is set to release 700,000 b/d of Iraqi oil onto world markets, could be completed in 7-10 days. But he added that could be an optimistic assessment and the process could take longer.
Traders said that mention of Iraq still briefly spooked the market.
